title: Obituaries: Cancer Disrupted A Stellar Career
text:
Kimberly Hammonds hopscotched through a career with executive posts involving increasing responsibilities for technology at Ford Motor Co., Dell Inc., Boeing Co. and Deutsche Bank AG.

In her mid-30s, breast cancer disrupted what looked like steady progress toward a chief executive appointment. "I felt like somebody was basically laying me on the floor and saying you now need to pay attention to what's important . . . not everything's about the career," she said in a video interview. She began pondering how she would be remembered.

A hospital volunteer introduced her to art therapy. Painting distracted her from the torments of chemotherapy. She began looking forward to hospital art sessions.

Ms. Hammonds decided that her legacy would be the Zoe Foundation, founded in 2004 and named after her daughter, providing art therapy for cancer patients.

After she was diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer in April 2019, she raised about $1.8 million for the foundation and assigned friends to carry on with fundraising work.

Over the past few years, Ms. Hammonds served as a director of companies including Zoom Video Communications Inc. and Box Inc. She was attending board meetings via remote links until a few days before she died on June 28 at her home on Anna Maria Island in Florida. She was 55 years old.
